head.title: New High School Is a Study in Green

hedline.hl1: New High School Is a Study in Green

block.p: From the composting of cafeteria waste in the basement to the roofing made of recycled tires, the High School for Environmental Studies is living up to its name.

The school, which started at the old Stuyvesant High in 1992, moved this fall to its permanent home in a three-building complex at 444 West 56th Street. Practicing what it teaches, the school set an earth-friendly example in designing the $23 million renovation of the buildings, formerly a 20th Century Fox studio and headquarters.
From the composting of cafeteria waste in the basement to the roofing made of recycled tires, the High School for Environmental Studies is living up to its name.

The school, which started at the old Stuyvesant High in 1992, moved this fall to its permanent home in a three-building complex at 444 West 56th Street. Practicing what it teaches, the school set an earth-friendly example in designing the $23 million renovation of the buildings, formerly a 20th Century Fox studio and headquarters.

The newly installed environmental features were conceived as a model for school construction and as a case study for its students. It was designed and built by the related MBA Municipal, Meli-Borrelli Associates and John Borrelli companies.

The school, which expects to reach full enrollment of 900 next fall, teaches special topics like environmental law, environmental health, marine biology, botany and horticulture, as well as standard courses.

Academic and extracurricular activities include testing Hudson River water for pollution, rock climbing, work with the Central Park Conservancy, a community garden in the Bronx and field trips to places like Alaska, Lithuania and Baja, Calif.
"People hear about the things we have and are quite amazed," said the principal, Alexander Corbluth. B.L. What Makes a Building Sensitive?
The environmentally sensitive features of the new building of the High School for Environmental Studies include the following. * Indoor wall panels made of recycled newspapers

* Ceiling tiles manufactured from processed seaweed * Energy-saving lights * Water-saving plumbing fixtures * Zoned heating and cooling with computerized controls * Insulating double-pane windows * Roofing composed of recycled rubber tires * Skylights for the gymnasium (3d floor of building on 55th Street side of complex) * A greenhouse atrium on the 6th floor (east side of roof) * A rooftop garden in planters made of recycled water-tower redwood with trees and other plants planned for the spring (west side of roof) * Recycling bins ordered for the basement for paper, cans and glass * Composting center planned in the basement * Weather-monitoring instruments on the roof (mid-building) * Room with special climate controls for raising animals (6th floor) * Dishwashers for permanent rather than disposable plates (4th floor) NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN
